doc.after: The painting was widely copied and imitated during the 15th century. Near exact copper reproductions were recorded in Bergamo and Turin. Petrus Christus borrowed the illusionistic carving on the parapet for his 1446 Portrait of a Carthusian.[33] A c. 1449â50 portrait of Marco Barbarigo attributed to a follower of van Eyck is heavily indebted, in that it is also unusually tall and narrow, with a large space above the sitter's head.[25]
